exercises.exerciseDescription:
Lymphatic drainage jumping

We promote the lymphatic flow and boost our metabolism in this exercise. Jumping can be replaced by running in place.
The best time for this exercise is in the morning when you just woke up and still did not even have a glass of water or so.

What does this jump-the-lymph-exercise give us?
- Lymphatic system receives support in cleansing from cell waste;
- The body is mobilized, the metabolism is accelerated;
- It is the number-one-treatment for skin laxity;
- Cellulite is reduced;
- Excess fluid is slowly removed, which results in reduction of edemas and all the edematous congestion.

Caution: The course is designed for conventionally healthy people. If you have any chronic medical conditions or have recently had a surgery, please do not jump.
Pregnant women should also not jump.

Ladies, hold your breast while jumping.
If you are overweight, you should start with easy jumping, which means a low jumping height and a lower number of jumps. You can increase the height and the number, when you feel like it.

Technique
- Find a free space with a solid floor.
- Go on your tiptoes and let your body weight fall naturally on your heels. Continue these jumps, gradually increasing the jumping height and the speed.
- Do about 30 to 40 jumps the first time. You can gradually increase the number of jumps up to 100 on the following days of practice.

Important!
Do not lift your toes off the floor, it is not necessary to bounce, but to hit the floor with your heels. The floor still can shake. Be sure to choose a solid floor.   

If you have swelling in your entire body, you can repeat this jumping exercise in the afternoon and in the evening, but not later than 1 hour before going to bed. These jumps are pretty invigorating.   

Listen to your body. Your sensations will tell you the correct jumping height and speed. The main rule in this business is regularity, not intensity.

Good luck!  

Powered by Froala Editor

Running in place

Shake it up!
This lymph drainage exercise can be substituted by jumping.
- Lymphatic system is cleansed from toxins.
- The whole body is mobilized.
- First cure for skin laxity.
- Cellulite is reduced.
- Excess fluid slowly goes away, which helps to get rid of edema and other edema related problems.

Caution: This kind of running is no sport! Our goal is to get our bodies to start vibrating to improve the  blood circulation from blood vessels to capillaries. So, you normally shouldn’t feel tired afterwards. 

Technique
Find a suitable spot where you can move freely in one place.
Simply start running in place. No need in big or sharp movements. It is much more important to slightly hop from one foot to another. That is the minimum you should try to perform. You can add some movements to your arms, too, if you want to boost the effect. Keep running for about a minute. Breathe evenly. 

Attention!
Do not tense any part of your body. Relax your shoulders, arms and hands. Shake them up, if you feel like doing this!

Take it easily!   

Powered by Froala Editor

Morning lymphatic face drainage

We always start working on the face with the lymphatic drainage techniques. At first, we perform the lymphatic drainage – the cleansing and only after that the manual tricks.

As a result of this lymphatic drainage technique:
  Facial volume decreases;
   The lymphatic transport system is refreshed, and healthy face lymph drainage is normalized;
   Cell decay products are removed faster;
   Skin appearance is improved due to a faster lymph cleansing;
   Pigmented spots are lightened;
   The skin elasticity is increased by getting rid of excess fluid.

Caution:  Please do not stretch the skin. The main movement is more of a sliding. The pressure should be very light, it is rather stroking.
If you have a skinny face, do this exercise only in the morning, not more than 3 repetitions at a time.
Be sure to use some skin moisturizer for this technique. Perform the exercise either on moist skin or ideally after applying a day cream or tonic. 

Technique
- You will need your both hands for this technique. Place the inner edge of your palms on the sides of your nose. The knuckles of your index fingers should be placed at the corners of your lips. The thumbs should meet under the chin area. Press the muscle under your chin with your thumbs before you start the motion.
- Slightly slide over your face with the inner edges of the palms towards the ears.
- When you reach your ears with the index fingers, run the fingers from the ears down the neck to the collarbones. After you reach the collarbones, on the exhalation, press in your fingers under the collarbone for 1 to 2 seconds.
- Repeat the exercise 2 to 3 times. You can perform the exercise up to 5 times, if you feel like it.

Attention!
You are probably asking yourself: Will I not stretch my skin too much?...  
Don’t worry, your skin will not stretch too much!
Do not forget about moisturizing and smoothing your face, and you will never have to ask yourself this question during the practice again.

If you have a full face, and you feel like it, repeat the exercise in the evening.
Observe the reaction of your face, and listen to your sensations.

Check out the 2nd video to see what your lymphatic system of the head and neck look like.   

Good luck!   

Powered by Froala Editor

Basic neck stretch exercise

This is an excellent neck exercise that can be done anytime. Have a moment? - Stretch your neck. In this case we use this exercise as a test to determine if you are ready for the next more advanced neck exercises. Please do it gently, carefully and listen to your sensations. The neck can almost always stretch but returning to the starting position can be difficult if the neck isn’t ready. Stretch it slowly and listen to the sensations in your neck.

Caution: When we say “slowly”, we mean it!    A sudden moving back from a stretched state can bring an unpleasant surprise such as pain or discomfort for those with an untrained neck.

Benefits of neck stretching:
- Tension in the neck muscles is reduced;
- Head/ neck posture is corrected;
- Double chin starts to shrink;
- The shape of the face is improved;
- Neck wrinkles are reduced;
- The skin on the neck is tightened.

Technique
- Stand up straight and stretch out your neck pulling the head upwards.
- Turn your head to the one side until you can’t go any further, hold it for 2 inhale-exhale-rounds, slowly return your head to its original position. Repeat the sequence for the other side.
- Tilt your head to one side until you can’t go any further, hold it for 2 inhale-exhale-rounds, slowly return the head to its original position. Then repeat the sequence for the other side.
- Very slowly and carefully move your lower jaw forward, do not overdo it. Without delay, slowly return the head to its original position.
- Pull the lower jaw backwards. And then stretch it upwards without throwing your head back. Keep pulling the lower jaw upwards, breathe evenly, deeply and hold it for 2 inhale-exhale-rounds. Then slowly return the head to its original position.

You can do this exercise several times a day, if you feel like it. Don’t forget to do it slowly and carefully every time.

If you do this exercise, it feels good and you don’t experience any sharp pain or discomfort, then you are ready for more advanced exercises that we will learn the following days.

If you suddenly feel discomfort or sharp pain, please stop practicing and listen to the sensations. Try to do small-amplitude head rotations at first. Does it work? Very well, perform these rotations, followed by very gently stretching motions until the discomfort in the neck goes away. Then you can move on to learning the more advanced stretches.

Sharp pain doesn’t allow you to move freely? ...  Well, in this case, stop practicing all the neck exercises and go see your physician.

Be gentle to yourselves, take care!     

 

Powered by Froala Editor

Head rotations

This is an amazing exercise which is going to help you return mobility to your neck! It is a basic exercise that you need to have always at your disposal. 

This exercise:

- improves your neck zone (cervical spine) functional mobility;

- warms up your neck muscles;

- dissolves possible congestion in the cervical zone;

- restores the physiological tone of the neck muscles back to normal;

- corrects the neck static;

- prevents osteochondrosis and arthritis in the neck area.

Caution: You can practice it any time of the day in any convenient situation. Do it before you start with other neck exercises and also after it. But start by doing it very very gently.

If you are doing it for the first time in your life, you may be surprised by cracking sounds and possible sudden aches. 

The technique:

  • Don’t forget to control your breathing while doing any exercise. Deep inhale and then long exhale without pauses.
  • Stand up straight, let your arms hang down relaxed, and reach upwards with the top of your head and relax. 
  • Let’s call it the crown of your head. It is also a nice to imagine that you have something very important on your head   .
  • Then slowly drop your head as if you would try to touch your chest with the chin while exhaling. 
  • Start to move your crown to the left and upwards doing semicircle while inhaling until your head gets to the position when the back of it looks down and you look up.
  • Continue the rotation from this position while exhaling by pointing your crown to the right then drop your chin down again. Imagine the crown drawing circles over your head. 
  • Continue rotations to the right and do it 4 more times. Do not speed up! Keep doing it gently even if you feel alright after the first circle.
  • Do the same rotations to the left side. 5 times. 
  • Keep doing it slowly and gently.
  • The larger circles you can draw with your crown, the more flexible and prepared for further exercises your neck is.

Attention! The technique is simple but please pay much attention to what you feel while doing the exercise. Any sharp pain can be a signal to cervical spine osteochondrosis. In that case you have to be very careful and attentive to your neck area. Any other exercise for your neck should be done very gently. 

Do not ask me to diagnose what can be wrong with your neck, I am not a doctor. Besides, in that case, you need to see a doctor in person to get the correct diagnosis.

Tale: PLEASE DO NOT THINK THIS IT IS NOT YOUR CASE! 

I made this mistake when I did this neck exercise for the first time at the age of 40, 8 years after my last yoga class. I thought I was still flexible enough and stretching my neck would be an easy task.

It WAS!  Very easy...    BUT I ended up with a lumbago in my neck area which kept me from doing any other neck exercises for the next half a year. I had to downgrade it and go through a rehabilitation course to return mobility, strength and healthy feeling in the neck. This course is now called "Take it easy", it consists of 20 easy exercises aimed at returning the mobility to your spine, and you can find this amazing course in the app. 

Extra: Head rotations can be done in a sitting position, too. The standing position is more preferred just because all the following neck exercises are done from a standing position.

Good luck!   


Have you tried?

I bet you have heard many interesting sounds by now! :))  Clicks, crunching and even cracks are kind of normal... They are even normally expected.

I have been doing this exercise every day for past 4 years. My neck still does some clicking and crunching from time to time, but a lot less than before and I am no longer having any concerns about getting a lumbago. 


Got sudden pain? Do not hesitate to consult your doctor!

Powered by Froala Editor

Complex of neck exercises. 1. Front

Exercise on the front of your neck.

Essential basic technique for your healthy neck!

- The neck gets longer and stronger;

- Mobility of the head increases;

- Tension is released;

- The front part of the neck is prepared for special techniques on the double chin zone;

- Indispensable preparation for the all next exercises.

Caution: As with all neck exercises, perform it very slowly and gently! If you do it correctly, you will feel comfortable at any time while exercising.

In this business, it is better to do it softly rather than zealously.

Breathe smoothly during any exercise. It is crucial for the result.

Technique

1 Action. Hands up, chin down

- Stand in the upright position with the crown pointed upward.

- Put your hands up and hold your elbows with the hands over your head, tilt your head forward with slight pressure. There could be some soft tissues between your chin and your chest, it is normal. If there’s any, just press it with your chin. 

- Keep pressing your chin slightly to the chest for the next 4 inhale-exhale rounds.

- Breathe evenly.

- After breathing out for the 4th time, start moving your chin up, drop your hands down and relax. 

2 Action. Stretching

- straighten the chin slowly further up, feel the stretching in the front part of the neck, keep this position for the next 4 inhale-exhale rounds.

Repeat it one more time, if you feel like it.

Attention! 

Do not let your head drop backwards completely when you bend the back of your neck backwards too. This is a mistake. This mistake can cost you possible pain and a lumbago, so please keep the back of your neck as elongated as it could be while stretching the chin upwards.


After stretching the front of your neck, be sure to do the exercise for the back of the neck also.

Take it easy!   

Powered by Froala Editor

Complex of neck exercises. 2. Nape

Exercise on the back of your neck.

Essential basic technique for a healthy neck! 

- The neck gets longer and stronger;

- Mobility of the head increases;

- Tension is released;

- The back part of the neck is stretched and more flexible;

- Indispensable preparation for all the next exercises.

Caution: As with all neck exercises, perform it very slowly and gently! If you do it correctly, you will feel comfortable at any time while exercising.

In this business, it is better to do it softly rather than zealously.

Breathe smoothly during any exercise. It is crucial for the result.

The word “compensation” here means a slight pressure against the main movement.

Technique

1 Action. Head back on hump

- Stand in the upright position with the crown pointed upward.

- Lock your hands together behind your lower back. Lift the locked hands upward as high as you can while keeping your arms straight. Your trapezoid muscles would shape up to a hump.

- Use the hump as a base for your head, slowly let your head drop on the hump.

- Stay in this position for 4 inhale-exhale rounds. 

- After exhaling for the 4th time, slowly start moving your head upwards while inhaling. 

- Fix your head in the upright position for a couple of seconds and move on to stretching.

2 Action. Stretching

- Lift your hands, lock them together with your fingers and place them on the back of your head.

-You’ll feel the weight of your arms slightly pushing your head down. Allow it to do so, but DO NOT push it down with strength. Just the weight of your arms is enough to do the trick.

- Tilt your head down, feel the tension in the back of the neck, relax your arms.

- Stay in this position for the next 4 inhale-exhale rounds. 

- Control your breathing. Breathe evenly in and out, do not hold the breath.

3 Action. Compensation

- After the last exhaling, while inhaling you slowly start moving your head upwards with your locked hands compensating for this movement with slight resistance. 

- Fix your head in a perfectly upright position. The head is slightly pushing against your locked hands.

- Stay in this position for 2 inhale-exhale rounds. Breathe deep and evenly.

Repeat the actions 2 and 3 for 2 inhale-exhale rounds each.

- Close your eyes for a few seconds and feel your neck and its new position.


Attention!

No pressure on the head, while it is tilted toward the chest. Just the weight of your arms should perform the natural pressure. If you think, your hands might be too heavy, you should be especially careful and try to compensate for the natural pressure in order to make it lighter.

This exercise is good on its own, but you should never skip it out when doing the neck complex.


Take it easy!   

Powered by Froala Editor

Complex of neck exercises. 3. Sides

Basics, basics for every day!
Exercise on the sides of your neck.

- Your neck gets long and strong;

- The side muscles of your neck are relaxed and better supplied with blood;

- Tension in your shoulders is reduced;

- Your head’s supply with blood also improves, which results in a relief of headaches and shoulder pain.

Caution: If you do it correctly, you will feel comfortable at any time while exercising.
Slow and gentle movements are the key to a healthy neck in this exercise.
The word “compensation” here means a slight pressure against the main movement.

Technique

1 Action. Hump

- Stand in the upright position, stretch your crown upwards, relax your shoulders and arms.

- Put your right hand on your waist so that your arm and a bodyside would make a triangle. Now stretch the long side of this triangle by lifting the right shoulder as high as possible. Your trapezoid muscle should make a hump.

- Use this hump as base for your neck and your head, tilt your head slowly toward the uplifted shoulder. Your neck must firmly meet with the hump that you created with your trapezoid muscle, the ear may not necessarily touch the shoulder - it is not what we are aiming for. The goal is to get a slight pressure of the contracted trapezoids on the right side of your neck.

- Control your breathing. Breathe smoothly. Try to make your breathing in and out equally long. 

- Keep this position for 4 deep inhale-exhale rounds; Return your head to the upright position and let your strained arm relax, spot the difference in sensations to the opposite side.

2 Action. Stretching

- Keep your head in the upright position. Put your left hand over the head as if you were trying to grab your right ear. Let your left palm rest on the right side of your head.

- Tilt your head slowly to the left – the opposite side of where you made a hump previously. The hump and the neck are getting stretched now.

- The hand rests on your head without any tension, keep it relaxed. The hand performs slight pressure using its own weight only. Do not push!

- Relax the shoulder of the arm that rests on your head.

- Control your breathing. Breathe smoothly. Try to inhale and exhale equally long. 

- Keep this position for the next 4 deep inhale-exhale rounds.

3. Action. Compensation

- Return the head slowly in the upright position. The hand now is compensating the return action of the head, keeping the neck in the stretched state. Let the palm be in the same place until the very end of the action.

When your head is straight up with your hand compensating it with a slight pressure, keep this compensating pressure for the next 2 rounds of breathing in and out. Both the head and the hand «want» to keep the head in the perfectly upright position.

Start slowly with the stretching action again. Stay in the stretched position for 2 inhale and exhale rounds. Return your head to the upright position with the compensating pressure by your hand.

Now let your hand down. Relax. Close your eyes for 5 seconds and spot the difference between the left and the right side.

Repeat the sequence for the other side of your body. 

Attention!

As with all neck exercises, perform it very slowly and be attentive to your sensations. If you do it right and keep your neck as long as possible in every position, you are not going to experience any discomfort.

! DO NOT try to reach shoulders with your ears. This can cause serious troubles to your neck; it is not the action we need. 


Tale:

Well, I do this exercise every day. At least once in the morning as a part of the neck complex. I also do it any other time of the day when I feel discomfort in the neck-shoulder area. It is a great relaxation technique!


Have you tried?

What were your sensations in the left and right side before you did the opposite side?


Take care of your neck! 
It is the pedestal for your pretty face     

Powered by Froala Editor

Neck complex of exercises. 4. Trapezius
Stretching the trapezius muscles.

- Your head posture improves;

- The neck gets longer and stronger;

- Tension in shoulders is released;

- Your head’s supply with blood also improves;

- The better feeling in the body as a whole.  

Caution: Please perform this exercise slowly and gently. Remember, be especially careful if you never trained your neck muscles, we don’t want to risk a lumbago. If you do the technique correctly, the neck will only get stronger and longer.

Technique

1. Action. Rest on the hump

- Stand up in the upright position with a hand on your waist, your thumb looking down and your middle finger pointing to the spine bone. Your palm is resting on the part of your body where you suppose your kidney. Move your elbow backwards. Your arm and the bodyside would make a triangle. Now stretch the long side of this triangle by lifting your shoulder as high as possible. Your trapezius muscles should make a hump. This hump will be the base for the back of your head. Now turn your head in the opposite direction to the hump and look upwards. The back of your head should comfortably rest on the hump. No extra tension here.
- Stay in this position for 4 inhale-exhale rounds. Breathe evenly.

2. Action. Stretching

- Return your head to the upright position and let your strained arm relax.
- With the other hand, take the back of your head, so that your wrist lies on the top of the head and fingers are pointing down. Ideally, the elbow would look outstretched. The hand here controls the following stretching.
- Tilt your head towards the chest, then move it slowly to the armpit of your controlling arm. Stretch your chin towards the armpit. Stay in this position for 4 inhale-exhale rounds. Breathe evenly, feel the muscles being stretched, starting from your skull and ending in your shoulder.

3. Action. Compensation

- Return your head to the upright position by going the same way back. The controlling hand compensates the movement, which has the effect of slowing down the return movement with its natural weight.
- Stay in the upright position for the next 2 inhale-exhale rounds. The controlling hand is fixing the head and doesn’t let it go backwards. Yet the all-up tension would be pointed up.

Repeat the stretching and fixing sequence and hold it for 2 inhale-exhale rounds each. 

Repeat the sequence for the other side of your body.

It is the last exercise of the neck complex. It is advisable to do the head rotations after it.

Attention!

The controlling hand is for control only. Do not push while stretching. Its own weight is just enough pressure. If you think your hand might be too heavy, do not let all of its weight lay on your head. Listen to your body and try to find the right pressure.

Do the neck complex of exercises every day, and soon you will be amazed at how much longer your neck would become.  


Take care!   

Powered by Froala Editor

Spinal traction, shoulder opening

Easy and effective exercise for opening the shoulders.
- Shoulders get more mobility.
- Chest is open, bringing relief to the chest-shoulders area.

Caution: Use the natural weight of your body. Do not push!

Technique
- Step up to a clean wall, place your hands with the outstretched arms on the wall at the forehead-level slightly wider than your shoulder.
- Take a step back while keeping the hands in the same place.
- Let your upper body bend down, feel the stretching in your chest and shoulder muscles (deltoid and pectoralis).
- Breath evenly. Stay in this stretching position for 4 to 10 inhale-exhale rounds.
- Return to the upright position and feel the difference, try to rotate your arms, stretch them upwards.

Attention!
If your shoulders are already flexible enough and your head (provided keeping a straight spine line) goes lower than your shoulders, the stretching should be performed as follows: the crown towards the wall… Well if you are that flexible, you surely already know how to do it.     

Relax, and take it easy!    

Powered by Froala Editor

Shoulders  stretching

Easy and effective exercise for opening the shoulders.
- Shoulders get more mobility.
- Chest is open, bringing relief to the chest-shoulders area.

Caution: Use the natural weight of your body. Do not push!

Technique
- Step up to a clean wall, place your hands with the outstretched arms on the wall at the forehead-level slightly wider than your shoulder.
- Take a step back while keeping the hands in the same place.
- Let your upper body bend down, feel the stretching in your chest and shoulder muscles (deltoid and pectoralis)
- Breath evenly. Stay in this stretching position for 4 to 10 inhale-exhale rounds.
- Return to the upright position and feel the difference, try to rotate your arms, stretch them upwards.

Attention!
If your shoulders are already flexible enough and your head (provided keeping a straight spine line) goes lower than your shoulders, the stretching should be performed as follows: the crown towards the wall… Well if you are that flexible, you surely already know how to do it ;)

Relax, and take it easy!    

Powered by Froala Editor

Stand against a wall

This exercise is the top of posture exercises!
This is an indispensable technique to bring your head in its healthy position. It is a static exercise, looks easy, but you must try yourself before you can judge. Performing it for the first time, try to do it for a minute, then you can gradually increase the duration, ideally up to 10 minutes a day.

Benefits:
- Neck posture is improved.
- The neck gets long and strong.
- You will find the real straight posture for your spine.
- Oxygen consumption increases as your lungs can intake more air in this pose.
- Nerve system is strengthened.

Caution: This exercise is not suitable for pregnant women.
You may feel dizzy, you may experience trembling in your calves and arms.

Technique
- Find a clean wall, ideally without a baseboard, so that your heels can touch the same surface that your head will lean on. There should be enough space over your head, so you can move upwards freely.

- Stand against the wall with your back to the wall. Your heels, calves, buttocks, back shoulder blades should be touching the wall.

- Straighten up your neck and point your «crown» upwards, lean the back of your head on the wall and look straightforward. You can close your eyes during the exercise, if you feel like it.

- Relax. Let all your muscles release the tension, only some muscles in the back are compensating this relaxation and keep your spine straight against the wall.

- While relaxing, keep your calves, back shoulder blades and the back of the head well attached to the wall. Correct the position, if they are not.

- Flatten your body gradually against the wall while keeping it relaxed. Your arms should be hanging relaxed.

If you are the one to go for 10 minutes every day - you are probably the king of posture! After a month of practice, you should check your height, don’t be surprised, if you get half an inch taller. 

Attention!
If you are overweight then getting your heels, calves and buttocks to touch the same surface would be difficult. In this case, step away from the wall just a bit, but surely keep your buttocks, back shoulder blades, and the back of the head to the surface.
You can get some strange sensations across your body, which are normally expected for beginners. It could be trembling, itching, a slight numbing in your legs and arms. It will gradually subside every day. One day you will find yourself resting in this pose, I promise.   

I feel like a new person every time after this exercise. From now on, this exercise is always there to help you improve your posture and ease the discomfort sensations in your back and neck. Nothing is as effective as this standing exercise to improve your neck posture.

Good luck!   

Powered by Froala Editor

Massage of the galea aponeurotica (GA)

Our skull (the cranial vault) is covered with a single muscular-aponeurotic formation - the cranial muscle, in which the following parts are distinguished:
• occipital-frontal muscle
• tendon helmet (supracranial aponeurosis or galea aponeurotica (GA) in Latin)
• temporo parietal muscle

The aponeurosis of the head (the tendon helmet), or, as it is otherwise called in Latin, galea aponeurotica (GA), is located under the scalp and directly connects the occipital-frontal muscle and the temporal parietal.
The appearance of our face depends primarily from these muscles.
With age, the adhesion process in our body is accelerating. Our body structures grow together, forming connective tissues in the wrong place or in excess of its healthy amount.

This process is also called tissue fibrosis.

Exactly the same process can occur with the GA. Our goal is to restore the mobility to the GA so that the tissues can return to their right place. When the GA is not flexible enough, the skin formed to folds and wrinkles on the neck and face wouldn’t return to its original position... So, please take this exercise very seriously!

Technique
- At first, we make an easy test. Press any place on your scalp with your index finger (frontal part where your hair starts to grow, crown, nape, or the most stubborn place behind the ears) and try to move the skin crosswise (right, left, forward, backward).
Does it move in all directions? How much does it shift? Does it shift at all the places?
Ideally, the shift should be about half an inch in each direction. The GA massage will bring you to these great results.

- The technique is simple and variable; you can take this massage creatively.    Our goal is to return mobility.
- You can use all your fingers, 8 or 10 as you wish. Place them on your scalp at any convenient place to start with and press the skin with your fingers to the skull. Start with crosswise movements (right, left, forward, backward). 2 to 3 will be enough, then you can move further to the nearby area about 1 inch further.
- Perform this technique all over the skull, all the hairy part of your head (including the parts where the hair growth has decreased).
- If you come across the parts that are completely resistant to a crosswise shift, you can try other massage movements: circular, shift to one side, pushing. There is room for creativity.  
- Harming yourself with this technique is virtually impossible, but the benefits from this exercise would grow in progression to your efforts.
- Ideally, the skin on the scalp should move along with the fingers. If your fingers slide a little through the hair, nothing wrong with it, it’s even useful for stimulating the hair growth. With GA massage, the blood supply to the hair follicles is significantly improved, the hair becomes stronger and grows faster.

Common question:
Can this massage make my hair fall out? I treat them with care ...  
Answer: The weak hair that you would lose anyway soon, may fall out. But it is a good thing, because new, healthier hair will grow there, if you keep doing the GA massage every day. The hair follicles are provided with a better nutrition, so that your hair would recover and grow fast. We have been seeing many happy followers whose hair growth has been restored. Take a look at our model, he is 45 years old, he has been practicing the GA massage (in different variations) since the age of 18, his hair is still thick as in his young years.

Practice well and enjoy!
Good luck!   

Powered by Froala Editor

Chewing muscles relaxation

Important technique to fight aging!
What can you get from it:
- Jawline angle (mandibular angle) returns to the original position and form.
- Chin is toned, back to the original form.
- Jawline contouring is better defined.
- Face shape is nice and tight. 

Caution: This is a very responsive technique. The chewing muscles may hurt pretty much the next day, if you overdo it. Perform it with only one-third of your power, please. Next time, you can increase the power. Listen to your sensations.

Check out what muscles you will work on


Technique
1. Action. Find them
- Using your fingertips, touch the tissues at the end of your jawline, above it, and next to the ear. Feel them all. Open your mouth and feel the difference. You will need to cover them completely with your palms.
2. Action. Pull them down slowly
- Use your palm’s full length for this action. The main working part would be the upper thumb section.
- Open your mouth slightly. Place your palm on the chewing muscles area. The palm is slightly touching the ear, the index finger is pointing upwards, the thumb is placed below the ear. The upper thumb section should be just above the beginning of the chewing muscles.
-Start sliding your palms down. For the first time, do it lightly. Later you will find just the perfect amount of pressure for this exercise. Harder doesn’t mean better in this business.
- Do 5 slides without increasing the pressure.
3. Action. Calm them down
- Finally, finish the exercise by performing a light massage on the chewing muscles using your fingertips. Feel it again, push it in a bit deeper. 

Attention!
Please, take it seriously about using a one-third of your power for the first time. It may really hurt the next day if you don’t follow my advice.

Tale:
Well, doing this exercise for the first time, I did not take it seriously. I did it with half the power instead of a one-third of it. It was quite a funny day afterwards. New sensations!    But don’t worry if you feel the same, let it rest for a day or two to recover, then practice again.

Good luck!   

Powered by Froala Editor

Soft-tissues mobilization of the forehead and smoothing the forehead

Caution: Please do all the face massage techniques with the power a one-year old baby could exert. Apply this rule to all the pressings, folding and frictions.

This technique is super effective! So, don’t get carried away! 

If you do this exercise for the first time, do it half-heartedly. 

In this business, it is better to practice a little but regularly rather than a lot at once.

Check out what muscles you will work on


Benefits
   Mobility of soft tissues of the forehead increases;
   Skins metabolism improves;
   Clogged lymph starts moving and removes the cellular waste;
   The forehead is revitalized;
   Horizontal lines on your forehead are getting smoother;
   Eyebrows are lifted up;
   Forehead hairline is better supplied with blood, which means better hair growth in the long-term.

Technique
- Clean your face and hands, as always before you start any massage technique.
- Place your elbows on the table, use the both hands.
- Place your fingertips on your eyebrows, press them slightly to the eyebrow bones and hold for 2 to 3 seconds, then slide your fingertips with all the soft tissues slowly towards the top of your head, stay in this position for 5 to 6 seconds and feel the tension you created.
- Relax the back of your neck, let your head rest on the fingertips.
- Keep the same pressure and start moving your fingertips together to the left and then slowly to the right, keep them moving horizontally through the soft tissues from the left to the right and back with the same pressure. Use the weight of your head to slide your fingertips little by little up to the hairline and a bit further through the hair.
- If you found a spot on your forehead that feels especially cramped and tensed - pay more attention to this spot but don’t overdo it.    It is better to come back to it the next day.
- Finish the left and right movements on the hairline, then return the fingertips to the eyebrows, but this time place the both hands on the left side of your forehead, so that the index finger of your right hand would be between the eyebrows.
- Press it for 2 seconds, move the soft tissues upwards, then stop for 5 seconds to feel your soft tissues, make the left-to-right movements with your fingertips, let them the reach the hairline and go a little bit further through your hair under the weight of your head.

- Repeat the sequence on the right side.

- If your skin is in a good shape, the soft tissues will move freely through the left-to-right movements leaving pleasant sensations.

Attention!
Please do all the face massage techniques with the power a one-year old baby could exert. Apply this rule to all the pressings, folding and frictions.

If you do this exercise for the first time, the sensations may be different from person to person. 

The good news is, it is hard to harm yourself using this technique.  
Try it and feel how your soft tissues respond!


Good luck!

Relaxing the procerus muscle

Take a look at the picture. 


Procerus muscle (also known as pyramidalis nasi or muscle of the proud).  Procerus is a small triangular muscle located between your eyebrows. 

When the procerus muscle is contacted it makes vertical wrinkles in this area. The muscle is contracted when you are concentrating for a long time, or when you are making a serious face. It helps you to look more serious but leaves unwanted lines right in the middle of your face. Now it’s time to relax it and smooth the marks the life left on your face.
- It is a great and also easy technique to bring the procerus muscle back in its original shape.
- Nose bridge lines are getting smoothed.
- Frown lines are smoothed too.
- Habit to frown is reduced.

Technique
1st step. Press into the muscles
- Use your both index fingers for this technique. Place your fingertips side by side on the bridge of the nose and press them into the muscle to the bone. Press hard, in this exercise you are allowed do so. Feel the pressure and hold it for 10 seconds.
- Slowly pull the fingertips apart until the eyebrows.
- Repeat the motion 3 to 5 times.
2nd step. Roll out
- Place your index fingers horizontally one over another. The hand of the upper finger would point up, and the one of the lower finger would point down. Place the fingers on the nose bridge with some pressure.
- Roll the fingers so that the hands would change the position from pointing up to pointing down and vice versa.
- After the rolling movement is finished, stretch this area by pulling the fingers apart a little.
- You can repeat the 2nd step 2 to 3 times.

All in all, it wouldn’t take more than one minute.

Attention!
For this exercise you won’t need any oils. You need a good grip on your skin.


Good luck!   


*The frontal muscle (‘musculus frontalis’ in Latin) is a muscle which covers parts of the forehead.

Powered by Froala Editor

Relieve tension in the middle of the forehead and between the eyebrows

Check out the muscles we will work on

Now is the time to start smoothing your frown lines!  
   Tension in the middle of the forehead is released.
   Nose bridge tissues are returning to their original place (myofascial soft tissue correction).
   Frowning is getting gradually out of the habit.
   Headaches caused by nervous tension are relieved.

Caution: This technique is very effective and easy to learn. In this exercise, you learn how to work with your fingers deep and slow. When we say "slow," it really means slow, about one millimetre in 5 seconds.

Technique
- Place your elbows on a table. Let the weight of your head lean the hooks. The back of your neck should be relaxed.
- Form your index fingers to “hooks”. Place both fingers on the nose bridge and push deep down to the bone. Feel the tissues for 10 to 20 seconds.
- One “hook” is the fixing one, you don't move it. The other one is the working one, you do move it, but very slowly, from the middle of your forehead towards the middle of your eyebrow.
- Return the “hook” to the start position. Repeat the action for the other side.
- Place the “hooks” a bit higher than your nose bridge. Now you can put them side by side with the finger joints touching each other. Push them in to the bone and keep them like this for 10 to 20 seconds. Compare your sensations to the previous position.
- Repeat the same slow movements using your working “hooks” for about 1 inch (2.5 centimetres)
- Place your “finger hooks” further up again. You may need to do it several times before you reach the hairline. Repeat the action.
- Going over the hairline is OK, it is even appreciated.  

Attention! 
The movements of the working finger should be deep and slow, but not too long. The fixing finger should not drop the pressure while the working finger is moving.

How did it go? Can you feel the relief already?

Take it easy!   

Powered by Froala Editor

Eyebrow puckering muscle massage

The Corrugator Supercilii Muscle


Benefits:
   Eyebrows look refreshed.
   Upper eyelids look fitter and toned.
   Anti-frown techniques help to maintain your forehead smooth.

Caution: Perform the exercise on clean skin only. No oil required for this technique. Remember the Baby-Power Rule while working with face and especially near your eyes. Eyelids are very sensitive tissues; they may be harmed easily when treated incautiously.

Technique
1 Action. Warm-up
- Make a fold out of the soft tissues of your eyebrow and the ones surrounding it, including the puckering eyebrow muscle using both hands. Start with massaging pinching-like movements with light friction, moving along the superciliary arch* from your nose bridge to the middle of the eyebrow.
2 Action. Stretching
- Make the same fold starting from the nose bridge. Start stretching the eyebrow muscle. The one hand is the fixing one, the other one is the pulling one. Pull the soft tissues along the fold towards the end of the eyebrow. The fold is thought to be about half inch long (1,5 cm). Place the fixing hand further to the end of your eyebrow and make another fold. You may need to do up to 3 folds one after another before you reach the middle of the eyebrow. Perform the pulling technique on every fold.

Repeat the sequence on the other side.

Attention!
Do not overdo it, please. If you do it right, it takes about a minute for each side.


Take care!   


*superciliary arch - a brow ridge of the frontal bone above the eye socket.

Powered by Froala Editor

exercises.exerciseName: Massage for the circular muscle of the eye
exercises.exerciseDescription:
Massage for the circular muscle of the eye

Eyes, eyes, eyes, let's help them!

Benefits of the exercise:
- Lymph drainage of the eye zone.
- Dark circles under the eyes and baggy lower eyelids are improved.
- Crow’s feet wrinkles decrease.
- Elasticity of the eyelids is increased.
- First treatment for the lower eyelid-cheek junction deformations.

Caution: The eye area has the most sensitive skin on our face. It can easily get harmed. Please remember in this exercise about the one-year-old baby power rule. Working on the eye area, imagine how gently a baby would touch the face, use the same power.

Check out what muscle you will work on


Technique
1st step. Warm-up
- Use all your fingertips for this warm-up technique. Perform a massage on the whole lower eyelid area, slightly pressing in the infraorbital margin* bones. 30 seconds would be enough for the warm-up.
2nd step. Frictions of lower eyelid
- Use your both index fingers. Make a little vertical fold of the soft tissues of the lid-cheek junction. You can grab about half an inch (1-1,5 cm) of soft tissues of the lower eyelid and below it, but please, do not squeeze it!
- Perform the massage on the fold, doing frictions very patiently and carefully. Take your time.
- When the fold slips out during the friction, make another fold in the next area, moving towards the end of the eye socket. Perform the same friction technique patiently. Work your way through the whole area. You can make up to 10 folds on each side, if you want to work the whole way through the eye area thoroughly and patiently. It is up to you. Listen to your sensations and the way your soft tissues respond, but do not overdo it.
3d step. Frictions of temples
- When you are done with working on the lower eyelid, move to the temple area. Work on your smile lines. Take a fold next to the corner of the eye and perform the friction massage of it. The skin in this area is less sensitive, so you can apply slightly more power for the friction massage.
- Work your way through the whole temple area by taking the next fold and moving closer to your hairline. You may need to make 3 to 5 folds in this area.
4th step. Stretch the wrinkles on the temples
- Use both hands for this technique. Both index and middle fingers are working here. Place them on the temple next to the end of the eye, where the skin is less sensitive than on the eyelids, one hand from above over your head and the other from below. The fingertips must meet before you start with the action.
- Push into the bone and hold it for 5 seconds, then pull both hands apart from each other for about an inch (2-2,5 cm) stretching the underlying tissues.
- Place the hands closer to the hairline and perform the same stretching technique. You may need to do it up to 4 times before you reach the hairline. Repeat the action. Going over the hairline is OK, it is even appreciated.

Repeat steps 2,3 and 4 on the other side.

Attention!
! The skin of the eye area is very sensitive. If you experience some discomfort or skin redness, reduce the power considerably.
! If you notice, the wrinkles of the eye area would become more definite, skip steps 2 and 3. Try it next week with reduced power.

Keep calm, be patient.  
Good luck!   


*The infraorbital margin is the lower margin of the eye socket.

Powered by Froala Editor

Kneading of facial tissues

A wonderful way to work on your middle and lower part of the face!
Check out what muscles you will work on


If you bump into some unevenness there, pay more attention to this spot and work on it a bit more. Inspect them carefully little by little.

- In-depth exercise for your facial tissues of the middle and lower part of your face, which gives a tender effect;
- Best preparation of the middle and lower parts for the following special correction techniques.

Caution: No oil needed for this technique. Your hands don’t need to slide over your skin. If you perform this technique for the first time, do it half-heartedly. 

Technique
1. Action. Cheekbones
- Use the base of your palms for this action. Place them on your cheekbones, thumbs facing your ears.
- Make rolling wave-like movements from the folds under your nose toward the temples. Repeat this action 5 to10 times.
- Place the base of the palms a bit higher, so that you would slightly touch the eye area during the movement. Repeat this action 5 to 10 times.
2.  Action. Cheeks
- For this action use the base of the thumb (also known as Venus mount). Place it at the corners of your mouth.
- Make rolling wave-like movements from the mouth toward your ears. Repeat it 5 to10 times.
3.  Action. Jaw
- Use the edges of your palms for this action. Place them close to your chin, fingers facing backward, the thumbs pointing down.
- Make rolling wave-like movements from chin toward the jaw angle. Repeat it 5 to10 times.
- Finish the exercise with the same movement placed a bit lower than the previous move.

Attention!
The technique is simple, so nothing to worry about here. Just be sure to do rolling movements, like a wave from the beginning to the end.
DO NOT slide with your palms over the skin. You don’t want to hurt yourself. 

Good luck!   

Powered by Froala Editor

Frictions on middle part of the face

That is a great exercise!
Very soon you’ll feel how effectively this exercise works on the facial tissues.   

Caution: This technique is very intensive. So, please, don’t overdo it! Otherwise, you can get a tissue inflammation. You know, they say “Give a fool rope enough…”  
Work with your face delicately, please. Just imagine how a one-year-old baby would be touching, pushing, pinching your face with its maximum power. You should not do it harder than that.

Benefits:
- Full face, puffy tissues and visibly uneven skin: the friction technique reduces the fat deposits under your facial skin making it firm and smooth;
- Skinny face: frictions help to revitalize the fat cells of your stored fat reserve, providing the necessary nutrition to accelerate the metabolism, and as a result, your fat deposits under the skin will recover!

Technique
- You need your both index fingers for this action. The first one is for fixing and should not be moved. The second one is the working finger and will perform the main action.
- Place your fixing finger on the center part of your cheek, so that the fingertip would point to the middle of your eye, and its beginning would rest in the middle of the jawline.
- Place your working finger in parallel to the fixing one near the nose (the middle joint of your finger would touch the alar wing of the nose).
- Move the working finger to the fixing one, folding your tissues. You should try to pick up as many tissues as you can. Your fold can be bigger or smaller than the one on the video. This is absolutely normal! We all have different fat deposits under the skin, different liquid levels, different qualities of soft-tissues.
- Start moving your working finger slightly up and down keeping the fold firmly. Little by little the tissues would escape from your fold as a result of your frictions. If it slips out too fast, return to the folding again. Don‘t do the frictions more than twice on the same spot.
- Move your fixing finger toward the ear with the distance of 1 to 2 times bigger than your finger. The working finger starts moving from the place where the previous fold has slipped out. Do the same foldings and frictions as previously. Then move the fixing finger again like you did before and repeat the frictions.
- You can do 3 to 4 foldings on each cheek. It is not necessary to do more than 4.

- Repeat the sequence on the other side of your face.

- There is another variation. If your fingers are tired you can straighten your palm and use it instead repeating the sequence 

Attention!

! Frictions should be done on CLEAN skin only! If you put on some oil or creme, your skin is going to be SO slippery! You won’t be able to hold your skin folded and work with it properly
Remember, in this case, “harder” doesn’t mean “better”.  Please, don’t squeeze the tissues between your fingers for dear life! 

! Skinny face: If you get a tired look after the frictions - stop practicing it and let your skin recover. Then start doing it again with half of the power and once in 3 days.

DO NOT THINK IT IS NOT YOUR CASE!  
I have made this exact mistake... until my loved ones would start noticing it. Well, recovery took some time, but everything is good after all. Remember the one-year-old kid touch rule and resume practicing 1 to 2 times a week.

Take it easy!

Massage of the muscle that lifts both the upper lip and of the wing of the nose (F1) and the muscles that lift the upper lip (F2)

The muscles you work out today not only lift the upper lip and nose wings but are also responsible for forming small bumps aside of the nose and nasolabial folds. Today you learn the first basic technique, so please pay special attention to these muscles.

At first, a little bit of the anatomy.

These muscles have long scientific names:
1. The muscle that lifts the upper lip and nose wing is called Musculus levator labii superioris alaequae nasi in Latin. It runs along the nose. Contracted it lifts the upper lip and the tip of the nose. The muscle is attached to the upper frontal process of the maxilla (visibly under the lacrimal canals of the eyes)  and inserts into the skin of the lateral part of the nostril and upper lip.(F1)
2. The muscle that lifts the upper lip (lat. Musculus levator labii superioris) starts at the infraorbital margin (the lower margin of the eye socket) above the infraorbital foramen (a small opening in the bone below) and inserts into the skin of the lateral part of the nostril and upper lip. (F2)
These both muscles are very important for facial expressions. They contract visibly when we smell something stinky and say "Phi ..". Therefore, as it is somewhat cumbersome to use their full names and for the sake of simplicity, we will call the one that is closer to the nose - F1, and the one that is farther from the nose - F2.
The F1 and F2 are the upper lip lifting muscles.
By contracting, they lift the lip and also form the nasolabial fold and the bumps above it. In a contracted state, the nasolabial fold is always present on the face ... and becomes more distinguished, if you do not relax these F lifters muscles properly.

So, let's start relaxing the F lifters muscles. At the same time, you get an excellent lymphatic drainage of the nasal area, which has lots of benefits:
- The nasolabial folds start to shrink.
- The asymmetry of the nose and the lacrimal grooves is leveled off.
- The bruises, dark circles and puffiness under the eyes starts to diminish.
- The F muscles are relaxed and prepared for the more advanced techniques.

Caution: Remember the rule of a one-year-old child’s strength. Do not hurt yourself. You should feel comfortable during the whole exercise. You can adjust the strength for this exercise yourself later. 

Technique
- You need both index and middle fingers for this exercise. Place them on the nasolabial fold so that the middle fingers are in the corners of the nose wings. The index and middle fingers are pressed together.
- Press in the soft tissues slightly, hold it like this for 3 to 5 seconds, and then begin small-amplitude circular massage movements. Circular motions in this case are similar to digging: inward, to the nose, then upwards with pressure, then outwards releasing the pressure and finally down.
- After a few circular movements, the index finger will reach the orbital bone. As soon as you feel this, raise your index finger, you no longer need it for the massage. Continue massaging with your middle fingers only until they reach the lacrimal canAls of the eyes.
- Slide your middle fingers to the nose wings starting from the lacrimal canals. The fingers go straight down the The muscle that lifts the upper lip and nose wing (F1). Feel them stretching and relaxing.
- Repeat it one more time. 2 sets shouldn’t take longer than a minute.
- When you are done with the exercise, smooth out the skin surface pressing it with your fingers and moving upwards from below. Try to “place” the skin the way you would like to have it. It shouldn’t take more than 5 to10 seconds.

Attention!
The exercise is easy and comforting but don’t get carried away too much the first time. Remember, in this business, regularity is more important than intensity. And the increased intensity in the early stages can lead to discomfort the next day, which may make you want to stop or take a break. And breaks during the study course are not really useful.

Good luck!   

Powered by Froala Editor

F1 muscle relaxation (the levator muscle of the nose lifting the upper lip and the wing of the nose) 

You can relax the F1 muscle using the technique of the ischemic compression and stretch the muscle using the myofascial correction. 

The benefits:

   easing the tension in the muscle responsible for lifting the lip and the wing of the nose;
   stretching the F1 muscle fascia;
   unevenness around the nose decrease;
   the nasolabial folds at the base of the nose are smoothed out



Technique

1 action. Warming up
We use the F muscle massage learned in the basic course. Let's take a good look at F levators, especially at F1.

2 action.
step 1. Compression
With one index finger, we fix F1 at the level of the orbit, pressing the tissue tightly to the bone. With the second index finger, we press all soft tissue from the wing of the nose to the fixing one, forming a fold of tissues, while we think about the muscle and try to squeeze it. We hold the clamp for 20-30 seconds. (4 inhale-exhale rounds)

Step 2. Pressing
We put both index fingers in the middle of F1 and sink them to the bone, hold the pressure for 5-10 seconds.

The task is to push the muscle in the middle, then stretching will follow.

In order not to be confused of the fact you could stretch the skin too much in step 3, you can push in, creating some additional skin fold for stretching beforehand.

Step 3. Stretching
Without releasing the pressure, we stretch the F1 muscle towards its beginning and end very slowly. The upper finger slowly moves to the lacrimal canal, and the lower to the wing of the nose. Ideally, movement should last the same amount of time as compression. When the fingers have reached the end points, we continue to hold the pressure on them for another 5-10 seconds and release.

Step 4. Soothing the skin
The top layers of the skin may look crumpled for a short time after such intense pressure and stretch marks. Let's help them find their rightful place as quickly as possible.

Using these light massage movements, you bring the skin back to the place where it is supposed to be. Pay attention to your sensations. After the first times you perform this massage, your muscle may ache a little, this is absolutely normal. 


Good luck!  

Powered by Froala Editor

Temple lift, eyes opener

One of the most important techniques for facial rejuvenation. A facelift in just 30 seconds is possible in almost any situation. 

   The upper eyelids are naturally lifted;
   The corners of the eyes are raised;
   The nasolabial folds are reduced.

The technique is simple, all you need is your hands for supporting your face and 30-40 seconds of your time. The lifting effect will be visible immediately. 

It surely will not last long after the first time, but if you keep on doing it every day, the effect will last longer with every day. The temporal region affects the appearance of the entire face, not only the eyes and forehead. So, it needs to be included into your daily routine, and as a result you will have a facelift effect without any surgery. Not kidding, practice well and see for yourself.      

Caution: You tighten the temples, not the eyes. So, please do not touch the skin around the eyes, it is very delicate.


Technique
- You need your both hands for this exercise. Place the base of your palms on the temples so that you do not touch the eyelids, the fingers are pointing to the crown.
- You slightly pull in your palms into the temples for 3 to 5 seconds. Place your elbows on the table, the head fixed between your hands, and relax your neck.
- As soon as you relax your neck, the head will naturally slide down under its own weight. Adjust the pressure with your palms so that your head slides down VERY slowly. This motion is over when the fingers meet at the crown. The way is short, so take your time. The slower you let your head slide, the better is the effect. 30 to 40 seconds should be enough for this motion.

Attention!
Be sure not to stretch your skin around your eyes. You work with the muscles of the temporal region on the deep level, not with the skin. The skin will tighten all by itself as the soft tissues under the skin improve.

From my personal experience, I can say that this is the fastest way to refresh your face in almost any situation. It is very fast and effective, if you for example need to look fresher for a photo.


Take care of your pretty eyes!      

Powered by Froala Editor

Massage of the circular muscle of the mouth

Do you want your lips to become plump? Then this is the right exercise for you!
But it is more than just for beautiful and full lips. This exercise tones the circular muscle of the mouth, which has a positive effect on the general appearance of the mouth.

Please remember that the rejuvenation is a complex process. So, leaving out a part of the face unattended can upset the dynamics of the process as a whole, even if you don’t see the effect right away. 

Caution: You work on the muscle (orbicularis muscle of the mouth), not on the lips, although you should also pay attention to the lips, especially at their relaxed state.

Check out what muscles you will work on


Technique
- Clamp the corners of your lips, in their usual position, with the outer edge or the base of your palms. Press them to the teeth. They should not slip out of this grip.
- Purse your lips forward and form them in a bell shape. At the same time, the border of your lips should be relaxed. Hold it for up to 1 minute.
- If you are aiming for beautiful lips, you can repeat the exercise up to 5 times a day.

Attention!
When you purse out your lips, you should constantly remember that the border of the lips must be relaxed. It is not always that easy to learn this right away. Go for it! 

Luscious kisses to you!  


Good luck!   

Powered by Froala Editor

Chin and lower jawline massage

What this first exercise of the triple set of basic exercises for chin and jawline can give:
   Stagnant decay products in the lower jaw get dissolved.
   Great technique to detect possible problems in the lower jaw.
   Chin and lower jaw are warmed up for next exercise.

Caution: Performing this exercise for the first time, don’t spend more than 1 minute on it, then do it according to your feelings. Be careful! Overdoing it can cause some skin irritations or bruises.
If you spot some knotted tissues, or something that may seem harder than tissues, work on it a bit longer, memorize this spot and come back to it the next day. 

Check out what muscles you will work on


Technique
- Form the index fingers to hooks. These hooks are going to do the main work. The thumbs are your fixing fingers.
- Place your thumbs under the chin and fix them firmly, at the first position the thumbs are touching each other.
- Place your hooked index fingers on the chin and press in for 20 seconds.
- Start with circling massage movements using your hooked finger. Keep the circles small. 5-10 circles are enough for the first time. Listen to your sensations.
- Move the fixing thumb to the next position towards your ear, so that “the hook” move on to the new area without leaving out any area of your jawline untouched. Move along the whole jawline and keep doing the same circling massage movements.
- When you reach the end of your jawline, you can use both index and middle fingers for more intensive massage of the big and strong chewing muscle.

Attention!
Perform the exercise on clean skin only, please. You won’t need any oils for this and the next couple of similar exercises. You’ll naturally force out some sebum (the secret of sweat and sebaceous glands) that would let your fingers move around smoothly without stretching the face skin. Don’t worry about it. Still worrying?    Well, then use a tiny bit of oil.

See you in a bit!   

Powered by Froala Editor

Smoothing the lower jawline

Time to get rid of unevenness and sagging cheeks!
Many muscles are crossing and building the jawline. Ideally, the jawline should be even and smooth. Unfortunately, it is not always like this. As we get older, it feels rather like a washboard. Any dysfunction of the jaw muscles can result in unevenness, bumps and sagging cheeks.
Good news!    This amazing technique can help you with it. Surely, the more you practice, the more results you see.

Caution: This exercise can be performed without any oils. You’ll see, you won’t stretch your skin. Don’t worry. Still worrying?    Then use a bit of oil for your hands.
As for men... man, you'd better shave your face before doing the exercise.   

Check out what muscles you will work on


Technique
- For this exercise, use the index finger formed to a hook that you used for the chin massage.
- This time the one hand is going to be the fixing hand and the other one is the working hand.
- Place “the hooks” on your chin, thumbs pressing carefully under the chin. Fix the one “hook” firmly to your jawline, the other one grabs the jawline firmly and starts moving towards the ear. The thumb under the chin is leading the action. It follows the jawline till the very end of it. It should pass the jaw angle and finish the action by touching the ear.
- When you spot a bump or any other unevenness, make a break from the exercise for a moment and give it a bit of a massage with your fingertips, then continue the smoothing action.
- 5 to 10 times are enough. Listen to your sensations, please. They normally give you the feeling of how many times are enough for you.

- Repeat the sequence on the other side.

Attention!
The smoothing action should be performed with a strong grab of your jawline,      quite seldom I use this word. But still, keep in mind that it is your face. Don’t overdo it, please.

Take care of your jaws!    

Powered by Froala Editor

Double chin massage

Benefits:
- Double chin is reduced.
- Jawline is toned and fit.
- Lymph circulation is improved.
- A great non-invasive treatment for lymphedema* and tissue fibrosis** in the neck.

Face tissue swelling is one of the main problems concerning the face shape, in general. Normally we do not waste any thoughts on it. We just accept the fact that the face is swelling as years pass. In fact, the main reason for this is a clogged lymphatic system which makes our skin look thicker. We normally put up with it until it gets too heavy and starts pulling parts of a face down, bringing such unpleasant effects like loose skin, puffy lower eyelid and nasolabial folds.
Most of the lymph fluid from the face region goes through the lymph nodes in the neck area. If the lymph transport system doesn’t work properly, it results in a clogged lymphatic system in the neck area. The more lymph is stagnating there, the more symptoms like uneven jawline, double chin, neck lines, fibrosis and lymphedema.
We are not going to dwell on the reasons for lymphedema, they are very complex and there are too many of them. Our goal is to make the lymph transport system work better in order to get rid of the unhealthy volume.

Technique
1. Action. Warm-up with large pinches
All in all about 1 minute.
- You need both hands for this exercise. Use your thumbs and the index fingers formed to hooks. Pinch the area below the jaw. Try to grab as much soft tissues as possible when you do the pinches.
- Work your way through the area of your neck from the chin to Adam's apple. You can even go further down under the Adam's apple, if you feel like doing it.
2. Action. Squeeze out excess of fluids
All in all about 1 minute for the both sides.
- Use the same thumbs and “hooks” but this time you work single-handed. On the right side you work with your right hand, on the left side with your left hand.
- Start working from the middle of the area under your chin. Take the thumb from the “hook” apart as much as possible. Place the thumb under the jaw angle, the “hook” should be under the chin. The thumb is for fixing and the “hook” is our working finger here. Squeeze out the soft tissues towards the thumb letting the flesh slip out from the pinch.
- As soon as the “hook” reaches the thumb, place the thumb closer to the ear and repeat the squeezing action. You may need to do up to 3 steps before you reach the ear.
- After that, place both the thumb and the “hook” further down along your neck and repeat the squeezing technique. Work your way through the whole area you warmed up in action 1.

Repeat the 2nd action on the other side.

Attention!
As always in this business, it is better to do it gently rather than zealously.
Especially when you do it for the first time. Later, you will figure out the correct amount of power you can apply.

Have fun!   

*Lymphedema is chronic tissue swelling that happens when the lymphatic transport capacity is exceeded.
**Tissue fibrosis is the phenomenon in which a tissue has a progressive deposition of collagen fibers with age. Tissue fibrosis is associated with aging of most of our organs, and it is the main pathology in arteriosclerosis, chronic bronchitis/emphysema, and benign prostatic hyperplasia. The causes and characteristics of fibrosis are analyzed with misrepair mechanism, a mechanism proposed in misrepair-accumulation aging theory.
